title: 114_s2526
content: The Act titled "Made in America Manufacturing Communities Act of 2016" establishes a program to designate and support manufacturing communities. The Act establishes a program to improve US manufacturing competitiveness by designating and supporting manufacturing communities. The program defines key terms and tasks the Secretary of Commerce with its implementation. The Act establishes a program to support manufacturing communities designated under subsection (d) by providing preferential consideration for financial or technical assistance under participating programs of agencies. The program supports manufacturing communities by giving preferential consideration for financial or technical assistance from participating agencies like the Department of Agriculture, Commerce, and Defense. The program supports manufacturing communities by providing preferential consideration for financial or technical assistance from various participating agencies including the Department of Agriculture, Commerce, Defense, Education, Energy, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, Transportation, Appalachian Regional Commission, Delta Regional Authority, Environmental Protection Agency, and National Science Foundation. The participating agencies for the program established under subsection (b) include the Department of Labor, Transportation, Appalachian Regional Commission, Delta Regional Authority, Environmental Protection Agency, National Science Foundation, and Small Business Administration. Each participating agency must identify applicable programs for the program. The participating agency must identify applicable programs for the program established under subsection (b), including those from multiple members of the same consortium seeking financial or technical assistance. The participating agency may determine preference for financial or technical assistance among members of the same consortium designated as a manufacturing community. The participating agency may determine preference for financial or technical assistance among members of the same consortium designated as a manufacturing community. If multiple consortium members are eligible for preference, they may be required to coordinate in developing their applications. Each participating agency must submit a report to the Secretary within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The participating agency may give preference for financial or technical assistance to members of the same consortium designated as a manufacturing community. The head of each agency must submit a report to the Secretary within 90 days of the Act's enactment specifying how preferential consideration will be given. The Secretary may provide a Federal point of contact to help consortium members access funds and technical assistance under the program. Under subsection (d), a Federal point of contact assists consortium members in accessing Federal funds and technical assistance. The head of a participating agency may award financial or technical assistance to a designated manufacturing community as deemed appropriate and in line with the consortium's economic development strategy. Recipients of assistance can use the funds for specified purposes. The consortium's economic development strategy allows recipients of financial or technical assistance to invest in ecosystems that enhance US manufacturing competitiveness. Investments may include infrastructure, access to capital, and promotion of exports and foreign direct investment. The support under this subparagraph may include infrastructure, access to capital, promotion of exports and foreign direct investment, equipment or facility upgrades, workforce training or retraining, energy or process efficiency, business incubators, site preparation, advanced research, and supply chain development. Coordination is done by the secretary of commerce. The Secretary of Commerce coordinates with participating agencies to identify programs for infrastructure, access to capital, workforce training, and more. Participating agencies also coordinate to leverage complementary activities and avoid duplication of efforts. Manufacturing communities are designated under this section. The Secretary of Commerce coordinates with participating agencies to designate manufacturing communities through a competitive process. Eligible consortiums represent regions and leverage complementary activities while avoiding duplication of efforts. Eligible consortiums for designated manufacturing communities must include at least one institution of higher education, a private sector entity, and a government entity, with the possibility of additional partners from these sectors. The eligible consortium for designated manufacturing communities must include a government entity and may also involve private sector partners, institutions of higher education, economic development and community groups, financial institutions, and utilities. The lead applicant must be a district organization as defined in federal regulations. The lead applicant for designated manufacturing communities must be a district organization, Indian tribe, consortium of Indian tribes, State, or political subdivision of a State. The lead applicant for designated manufacturing communities can be a district organization, Indian tribe, State, political subdivision, institution of higher education, or nonprofit organization. The lead applicant for designated manufacturing communities can be a district organization, Indian tribe, State, institution of higher education, or nonprofit organization. A consortium representing a region must be large enough to contain key technologies and small enough for close collaboration. Each designation under paragraph (1) lasts for 2 years and can be renewed for another 2 years upon application. The region defined must contain key technologies and enable close collaboration among consortium members. The Secretary may renew a designation for an eligible consortium for 2 years upon application, allowing modifications in composition. The Secretary may renew a designation for an eligible consortium, allowing modifications in composition, based on specified criteria. To renew a designation of an eligible consortium, the Secretary assesses performance against previous terms and post-designation awards, as well as progress on project-specific metrics proposed in the application. The Secretary evaluates the consortium's performance based on metrics in the application for designation renewal, potential changes to improve competitiveness, and other relevant criteria. An eligible consortium seeking a designation under paragraph (1) must submit an application to the Secretary, including a description of regional boundaries and manufacturing activities. Each application from an eligible consortium must include the regional boundaries, manufacturing concentration, and a competitive ranking assessment. The application from an eligible consortium must include a competitive ranking assessment and an integrated assessment of the local industrial ecosystem, along with an evidence-based plan for developing manufacturing activities in the region. The eligible consortium must provide a competitive ranking assessment, an integrated assessment of the local industrial ecosystem, and an evidence-based plan for developing manufacturing activities in the region, including specific investments and implementation strategies. The eligible consortium must provide a competitive ranking assessment, an integrated assessment of the local industrial ecosystem, and an evidence-based plan for developing manufacturing activities in the region, including specific investments, implementation strategies, outcome-based metrics, benchmarks, milestones, and evaluation methods to improve manufacturing in the region. The consortium will use evaluation methods to track performance in improving manufacturing in the region. The Secretary will evaluate applications based on regional cooperation and national manufacturing competitiveness. The Secretary will evaluate applications based on regional cooperation and national manufacturing competitiveness, including assessing the significance of regional cooperation and the competitive ranking of manufacturing concentration nationally. Certain communities previously recognized as manufacturing communities will be deemed designated under this subsection. The Secretary may accept transferred funds from other agencies to carry out the initiative.
